perturbation.original_text:
Affiliate shall actively promote the Service consistent with its business judgment, including the broadcast by each Station
transmitting the Service of an average of at least ten (10) thirty (30)-second promotional announcements per week for the Service (“Promotional
Spots”) on the Station’s Primary Feed, including the Station’s analog signal for so long as the Station broadcasts an analog signal, on a run-of-
station basis, commencing no later than the first air date of the Service on the applicable Station. Affiliate will submit program listings for the
Service to local print and on-screen guides. Additionally, Affiliate will provide a link to Network’s website (i.e., URL www.thetubetv.com or any
replacement or supplemental URL) on the websites of each of the Stations.
perturbation.changed_text:
Affiliate will consider to promote the Service consistent with its business judgment, including the broadcast by each Station
transmitting the Service of approximately ten (10) thirty (30)-second promotional announcements per week for the Service (“Promotional
Spots”) on the Station’s Primary Feed, including the Station’s analog signal for so long as the Station broadcasts an analog signal, on a run-of-
station basis, commencing no later than the first air date of the Service on the applicable Station. Affiliate may submit program listings for the
Service to local print and on-screen guides. Additionally, Affiliate will endeavor to provide a link to Network’s website (i.e., URL www.thetubetv.com or any
replacement or supplemental URL) on the websites of each of the Stations.
perturbation.explanation: The original text says Affiliate 'shall actively promote' and 'will submit program listings' 'will provide a link'. This has been changed to the following: 'will consider to promote', 'may submit program listings', 'will endeavor to provide a link.' This change weakens the obligation by making the promotion and submission of program listings optional rather than mandatory. The term 'will consider' is vague and does not guarantee any promotional effort. Making 'will submit' to 'may submit' creates uncertainty around whether the listing is mandatory or not. Furthermore, using 'will endeavor' suggests that they will try, but not necessarily succeed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: FCC regulations regarding Public Service Announcements (PSAs) and community involvement. While not directly a violation, weakening promotional requirements can be seen as a failure to adequately serve the public interest, a core tenet of FCC licensing.

perturbation.original_text:
Each Station agrees to transmit the Service on a full-time basis 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, except in cases of force
majeure, emergency broadcasts, when a Station’s Primary Feed is not being transmitted, as provided in 4(c) above, or when a Station must stop
broadcasting for maintenance or repairs. Each Station will provide Network with up to 5.0 mbps, but, at all times, not less than 2.0 mbps, for this
purpose, except as required in infrequent and exceptional circumstances resulting from a Station’s carriage of the primary television network with
which such Station is affiliated with regard to its Primary Feed (e.g., ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox). Except for a Station’s Local Advertising Time and
Local Programming, station identification messages, and as except provided in 4(c) and 4(e) above, each Station shall transmit the Service without
alteration, editing or delay.
perturbation.changed_text:
Each Station should consider to transmit the Service on a full-time basis 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, except in cases of force
majeure, emergency broadcasts, when a Station’s Primary Feed is not being transmitted, as provided in 4(c) above, or when a Station deems it necessary to stop
broadcasting for maintenance or repairs. Each Station will attempt to provide Network with up to 5.0 mbps, but, when reasonably possible, not less than 2.0 mbps, for this
purpose, except as required in infrequent and exceptional circumstances resulting from a Station’s carriage of the primary television network with
which such Station is affiliated with regard to its Primary Feed (e.g., ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox). Except for a Station’s Local Advertising Time and
Local Programming, station identification messages, and as except provided in 4(c) and 4(e) above, each Station shall transmit the Service without
alteration, editing or delay.
perturbation.explanation: The initial text says 'Each station agrees to transmit the service' but is changed to 'Each station should consider to transmit the service' weakening the legal responsibility. Additionally, it changes 'when a Station must stop broadcasting for maintenance or repairs' to 'when a Station deems it necessary to stop broadcasting for maintenance or repairs'. It is at the station's discretion to stop broadcasting. Furthermore, it changed from 'Each Station will provide Network with up to 5.0 mbps, but, at all times, not less than 2.0 mbps' to 'Each Station will attempt to provide Network with up to 5.0 mbps, but, when reasonably possible, not less than 2.0 mbps.' This changes the conditionality when providing the Network with speeds.
perturbation.contradicted_law: FCC regulations regarding broadcast service requirements. By weakening the requirement to transmit the service full-time, the station could potentially fail to meet its obligation to provide consistent service to its licensed community.

perturbation.original_text:
Network also shall display and encode program ratings for
the Service using the industry-standard “V-chip” ratings system.
perturbation.changed_text:
Network will consider to display and encode program ratings for
the Service using the industry-standard “V-chip” ratings system.
perturbation.explanation: The original text says Network 'shall display and encode program ratings' but it's changed to 'Network will consider to display and encode program ratings'. This introduces ambiguity because it's not legally binding anymore and can be broken. This goes directly against the rule.
perturbation.contradicted_law: FCC regulations regarding the V-chip and program ratings (47 CFR § 73.673). This regulation mandates the use of a program rating system to enable parents to block inappropriate content. By making the display and encoding of ratings discretionary, the contract undermines the purpose of this regulation.
